G.L. c. 212, \u00a7\u00a7 3 and 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, §§ 3 and 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the Defendant maintains and conducts business within Suffolk County.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County under G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this Complaint occurred in Boston, Massachusetts.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).support_reasoning: The court explicitly states a general Massachusetts tort principle that "every actor" owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, subject to foreseeability. The opinion cites Remy and the Restatement for this rule and then applies it, making clear that a duty arises where harm is reasonably foreseeable. This directly aligns with the proposition that, under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the elements of negligence and focuses on causation and statutory issues; it does not articulate or adopt a general statement that every person in Massachusetts owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others. The court expressly declines to decide whether the defendant owed a duty of care, resolving the case instead on lack of proof of causation. Thus, it does not provide authority for the broad duty proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694 (2000).relevant_excerpt: The motion judge found that the plaintiffs had not shown the requisite control necessary to impose a duty on the defendant. Because the plaintiffs have failed to meet their burden on the issue of causation, we need not decide whether they presented sufficient evidence to show that the defendant owed a duty of care to them sufficient to survive the defendant’s motion for summary judgment.

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (prohibiting openi.raw_text: G.L. c. 90, § 14 (prohibiting opening a vehicle door unless it is safe to do so)
G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14 (prohibiting openi.proposition: Defendant, through its employee, owed Plaintiff a duty to operate and manage the rideshare vehicle in a safe and lawful manner, including taking reasonable precautions before opening a car door into an active bike lane.

Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.raw_text: Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mass. 37, 45 (2009) (negligence consists of failure to exercise that degree of care which a reasonably prudent person would exercise under similar circumstances)
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.proposition: The driver breached this duty by failing to check his surroundings, opening the door without warning, and diverting his attention to his phone.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.support_reasoning: The case is cited in the prompt for the general definition of negligence as failure to use reasonable care under the circumstances, but the quoted opinion text does not address, apply, or discuss any facts involving a driver, checking surroundings, opening a car door, or using a phone. It focuses on whether a hospital owes a duty to a third party and issues of duty, special relationships, and scope of risk, not on the specific type of breach alleged here. Thus it cannot be authority for the proposition that this particular driving conduct constituted a breach, only for the abstract negligence standard.
Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc., 454 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage.”

Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicin.raw_text: Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicine, 437 Mass. 382 (2002)
Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicin.proposition: The actions of the driver constituted negligence per se under G.L. c. 90, § 14, and that negligence is imputed to Defendant.
Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicin.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurring opinion in Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicine and concerns victims’ statutory rights to participate in criminal proceedings under G.L. c. 258B. It does not address motor vehicle accidents, G.L. c. 90, § 14, negligence per se, or imputation of a driver’s negligence to a defendant. Therefore, this case does not support the proposition that the driver’s conduct constituted negligence per se under G.L. c. 90, § 14, or that such negligence is imputed to the defendant.
Benn v. Board of Registration in Medicin.relevant_excerpt: "The court, while conceding that the victim is not a party, nevertheless creates a right of victims to participate in the proceeding as a nonparty. That is judicial legislation designed to fill a void in the statutory procedure. In G. L. c. 258B, § 3 (l), the Legislature has declared a statement of principle, but has provided no means of implementing that principle other than by permitting victims to seek assistance from the victim and witness assistance board, the district attorney or the Attorney General..."

Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.raw_text: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 Mass. 320, 326 (1974)
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.proposition: It was foreseeable that opening a car door into a public bike lane without checking for traffic could cause serious bodily injury to cyclists.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.support_reasoning: The Afienko opinion concerns premises liability for a window washer injured when an anchor bolt failed, and discusses workers’ compensation common employment, hidden defects, and safety regulations for window-cleaning equipment. It does not involve motor vehicles, bicycle lanes, dooring incidents, or foreseeability of harm to cyclists from opening a car door into traffic. Therefore it provides no authority for the proposition about foreseeability of injury to cyclists from opening a car door in a bike lane.
Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston, 365 M.relevant_excerpt: We believe the jury could find on this evidence that the window washing done by Industrial on the club’s premises... was a dangerous task requiring specialized training and equipment... The plaintiff was the employee of an independent contractor working on the club’s premises. The club thereby owed him the same duty it owed its own employees — to disclose hidden or concealed defects on the premises of which it was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care.

Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 400 Mass. 6.raw_text: Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 400 Mass. 640, 646 (1987)
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 400 Mass. 6.proposition: Defendant also had a duty to properly hire, train, and supervise its drivers to ensure compliance with traffic and safety laws.

Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182, 190 (2.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to ensure that its drivers followed safe unloading and door-opening procedures, by failing to train drivers on bicycle safety awareness, and by tolerating distracted driving while engaged through its platform.
Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182, 190 (2.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Coombes v. Florio contains only the disposition (reversal of summary judgment and remand) and a note about separate opinions. It does not discuss duties regarding training drivers, unloading procedures, bicycle safety awareness, or distracted driving. Therefore, this opinion text cannot be said to support the detailed negligence proposition claimed.
Coombes v. Florio, 450 Mass. 182, 190 (2.relevant_excerpt: “The judgment of the Superior Court granting the defendant’s motion for summary judgment is reversed. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings. So ordered.”

Matsuyama v. Birnbaum, 452 Mass. 1, 6\u2.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence and the negligence of its agent, Plaintiff suffered physical injury, pain, mental anguish, monetary loss, and property damage.
Matsuyama v. Birnbaum, 452 Mass. 1, 6\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion addresses medical malpractice, causation, and recognition of loss-of-chance damages in wrongful death actions, not the general proposition that a defendant’s negligence caused a plaintiff to suffer physical injury, pain, mental anguish, monetary loss, and property damage. While the case involves pain, suffering, and economic loss from medical negligence, it does not articulate or adopt a broad rule about these categories of damages, nor does it mention property damage at all. Therefore it does not serve as direct authority for the proposition as stated.
Matsuyama v. Birnbaum, 452 Mass. 1, 6\u2.relevant_excerpt: “They found as well that the physician’s negligence was a ‘substantial contributing factor’ to the decedent’s death. They awarded $160,000 to the decedent’s estate for the pain and suffering caused by the physician’s negligence, and $328,125 to the decedent’s widow and son for the decedent’s loss of chance… We conclude that recognizing loss of chance in the limited domain of medical negligence advances the fundamental goals and principles of our tort law.”

Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mas.raw_text: Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mass. 270 (2006)
Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mas.proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence and the negligence of its agent, Plaintiff suffered physical injury, pain, mental anguish, monetary loss, and property damage.
Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mas.case_name: Carey v. New England Organ Bank
Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address or establish any rule about damages or the types of injuries recoverable as a direct and proximate result of negligence. It is a statutory immunity and good-faith case under the Uniform Anatomical Gift Act, focused on compliance with statutory requirements and immunity, and ultimately affirms summary judgment for defendants. There is no holding that a defendant’s negligence caused the plaintiff physical injury, pain, mental anguish, monetary loss, or property damage; in fact, liability is rejected.
Carey v. New England Organ Bank, 446 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, with respect to the sole instance of statutory noncompliance, the plaintiffs have not carried their burden of demonstrating a lack of good faith. See G. L. c. 113, § 13(c). Summary judgment was appropriate with respect to the failure to record the gift.… Judgment affirmed.”

Kelly v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659 (1985).proposition: Plaintiff has incurred and will continue to incur out-of-pocket expenses for medical treatment, dental care, and bicycle replacement, along with lost wages and other damages.
Kelly v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659 (1985).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a resident physician was a public employee entitled to immunity under the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act and whether summary judgment was proper. It does not discuss the plaintiff’s specific damages, such as medical or dental expenses, bicycle replacement, lost wages, or other out-of-pocket losses. Therefore, it provides no authority for the asserted proposition about the plaintiff’s incurred and future expenses and damages.
Kelly v. Rossi, 395 Mass. 659 (1985).relevant_excerpt: This tort action was commenced against the defendant doctor (doctor) and the Joseph P. Kennedy Memorial Hospital (hospital) based on a claim of negligent treatment of Duane Kelley in March, 1982. … The plaintiff claims that the doctor and the hospital were negligent in failing promptly to diagnose the boy’s condition and to advise his parents of it. It is alleged that Duane died of the condition that had not been properly diagnosed.

Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 768 (2001)
Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Plaintiff has incurred and will continue to incur out-of-pocket expenses for medical treatment, dental care, and bicycle replacement, along with lost wages and other damages.
Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 7.case_name: Nagel v. Provident Mutual Life Insurance Co. of Philadelphia
Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a dispute over cancellation of a life insurance policy and related contract, good faith, and statutory interest issues. It does not address or mention any facts or legal rulings about a plaintiff incurring out-of-pocket medical, dental, bicycle replacement expenses, lost wages, or similar damages. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for that damages-related proposition.
Kaminski v. Teverow, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: On January 11, 1995, Sandra Caulfield (Sandra) was killed by her husband, William, who thereafter committed suicide. The principal question before us is whether prior to her death Sandra effectively cancelled a $500,000 life insurance policy issued by the defendant insurer. A judge of the Superior Court concluded that the policy was still in effect and allowed the plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment on two counts of his complaint. We affirm in part and reverse in part.
